div.p: NotwithÅ¿tanding which Å¿aid appeale, a Å¿peciall High CommiÅ¿Å¿ion Court, was Å¿hortly after called at London, conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of 4, or 5 Doctors, where the Å¿aid CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners proceeded illegally, to Å¿uÅ¿pend the Petitioner in his abÅ¿ence, by meanes whereof, as of the threatnings of the Å¿aid CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, he was enforced to keepe his houÅ¿e, untill a Sergeant at Armes, with divers PurÅ¿evants, and other armed Officers, aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted by Alderman Abell, then Sheriffe of London, beÅ¿et the Petitioners HouÅ¿e, at 11 of the Clocke at night, and violently broke open his dores, with Iron Crowes, and the like, and Å¿urpriÅ¿ed him in his houÅ¿e, he making no reÅ¿iÅ¿tance at all: where having firÅ¿t Å¿earched his Å¿tudy, and taking away Å¿uch bookes as they pleaÅ¿ed, they carried your Petitioner to priÅ¿on, whence, the next day being the Å¿econd of Febr. by a pretended order from the Lords of the CounÅ¿ell, hee was conveyed to the Fleet, and there kept cloÅ¿e priÅ¿oner.

During which impriÅ¿onment, an information was exhibited againÅ¿t the petitioner, and others, in his MajeÅ¿ties Court of Star-Chamber, whereby he was charged (inter alia) with the publiÅ¿hing of a certaine Booke, containing, an Apologie for an Appeale, with his Å¿aid two Sermons, intituled, For God and the King, wherein hee taught Subjects to yeeld all manner of due obedience to their lawfull King, and reproved all lawleÅ¿Å¿e Innovations in Religion &c. Which Information, the petitioner upon his Oath under
the hand of M. Holt, being then of his counÅ¿ell, aÅ¿Å¿igned by Å¿peciall order from the Å¿aid Court, did put in his anÅ¿wer, wherein hee alledged Å¿uch things onely, as his Å¿aid CounÅ¿ell conceived to be materiall, and pertinent for his juÅ¿t defence in publiÅ¿hing the Å¿aid booke, but denyed all other matters in the Å¿aid Information conteined, which Å¿aid AnÅ¿wer, being admitted and received in Court, the petitioner (being then a cloÅ¿e priÅ¿oner) not onely attended the exhibiting of Interrogatories, according to the cuÅ¿tome of that Court, but withall, after Å¿ome univerÅ¿all delay, did write unto the Kings Attourney to haÅ¿ten them: but before the examiner came, the petitioner heard that his Å¿aid AnÅ¿wer was referred to S. Iohn BramÅ¿ton, Knight, Lord chiefe JuÅ¿tice of the Kings Bench: Sir Iohn Finch, then chiefe JuÅ¿tice of the Commonpleas, and was by them wholy expunged as impertinent and Scandalous (Å¿ave onely the not guilty) And the Petitioner underÅ¿tanding the anÅ¿wer he was to make to the Interrogatories was to be reckned as a part of his anÅ¿wer, admitted in court, but afterwards expunged as impertinent & Å¿candalous (as aforeÅ¿aid): Å¿o as if he Å¿hould then have anÅ¿wered the Interrogatories, he Å¿hold thereby have aÅ¿Å¿ented to the Å¿aid act of the Å¿aid Iudges, and Å¿o to the condemnation of his cauÅ¿e before the hearing, wherby he Å¿hould have contracted his former Oath, that his Å¿aid AnÅ¿wer was a true AnÅ¿wer, and Å¿o Å¿hould juÅ¿tly have brought himÅ¿elfe under the guilt of wilfull perjury,

For that very reaÅ¿on he held himÅ¿elfe not bound, (as hee conceived) to anÅ¿wer the Interrogatories, for that his Å¿aid anÅ¿wer was Å¿o expunged, and the (Not Guilty) as the foot Å¿o tyed to the head without the maine body (and that in the Judges owne words) as the Petitioner could not in any Å¿ort take or acknowledge it now for other then the Judges owne anÅ¿wer, as may appeare upon Record in the Å¿ame Court.

NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e, the Court taking the Å¿ame information Pro confeÅ¿Å¿o, and refuÅ¿ing to admit a copy of the Petitioners own true anÅ¿wer, as alÅ¿o of his reaÅ¿ons of not anÅ¿wering the Interrogatories, both which at his CenÅ¿ure he tendred to the Court, deÅ¿iring they might be then and there publikely read the 14. of Iune, 13. Caroli Regis, proceeded to cenÅ¿ure, whereby your Petitioner was CenÅ¿ured in a Fine of 5000. li. to his Majesty, To be deprived of his EccleÅ¿iaÅ¿ticall Benefice, degraded from his MiniÅ¿teriall function and degrees in the VniverÅ¿ity, and ordered to be Å¿et on the Pillory, where both his eares were to be cut off, confined to perpetuall cloÅ¿e impriÅ¿onment in LancaÅ¿ter CaÅ¿tle, debarred the acceÅ¿Å¿e of his wife or any other, to come to him, but onely his Keeper, and denied the uÅ¿e of penne, inke, and paper. And after his cloÅ¿e impriÅ¿onment for twelve weekes in the common Gaole in the Å¿aid CaÅ¿tle, he was (by what extrajudiciall order he knows not) tranÅ¿ported by the conduct of one Brian Burton appointed

div.head: The humble Petition of Nathanael Wickings Å¿ervant to MaÅ¿ter Prinne, and late priÅ¿oner in the White-Lion in Southwarke.
div.p: THat more then 3 years and a half Å¿ince, your Petitioner, being Å¿ervatn to MaÅ¿ter William Prinne then priÅ¿oner in the Tower, pending the laÅ¿t Information againÅ¿t his Å¿aid MaÅ¿ter in the Star-chamber, was apprehended in the Tower by a MeÅ¿Å¿enger, by a warrant from the ArchbiÅ¿hop of Canterbury and other Lords, and by him determined cloÅ¿e priÅ¿oner by the Å¿pace of tenne weekes, that none could Å¿peake with him but his MajeÅ¿ties Attourney General, & his MajeÅ¿ties then Solicitor, who examined him three Å¿everall times, upon Å¿ecrets of his Å¿aid MaÅ¿ters, to extort Å¿ome matter of accuÅ¿ation againÅ¿t his Å¿aid MaÅ¿ter by Dures.

That after tenne weekes end, your Petitioner was from that cloÅ¿e cuÅ¿tody by warrant from the CounÅ¿ell Board delivered over into the hands of Iohn Ragge, a MeÅ¿Å¿enger attendant upon the High CommiÅ¿Å¿ion Court, to be by him delivered to the Keeper of the Gate-houÅ¿e: But
the Å¿aid Ragge carryed your Petitioner home to his owne houÅ¿e, and there detained him two dayes and a night, till Å¿ome of the High-CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners had Å¿igned a warrant for your Petitioners commitment to the Counter in Woodstreet, whereto he was carryed by the Å¿aid Ragge, and charged with 26 Å¿hillings as his Fees due to him for the two dayes and nights he kept your Petitioner without order.

That your Petitioner was after called before the High CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners at Lambeth, and there tendred the oath Ex officio, to wit, to anÅ¿wer all Å¿uch Articles as Å¿hould be objected againÅ¿t him without ever being permitted, either to Å¿ee or heare them, though hee deÅ¿ired the Å¿ame. And for his refuÅ¿ing the Å¿aid Oath, the Court declared him pro ConfeÅ¿so, and by their unanimous cenÅ¿ure impoÅ¿ed a Fine of 1000 lib. on him, good round coÅ¿ts of Å¿uite, excommunicated and committed him backe to remaine Sub Å¿alva & arcta cuÅ¿todia, and not at any termes to walke abroad with his Keeper, untill other order Å¿hould be taken by the Court. One of the Å¿aid Articles, (to which hee could give no anÅ¿wer) running in theÅ¿e words.

Item, we obiect to you Nath. Wickins, that you know or believe that the letter, which you carried to the Printer, to be Å¿et the first Letter upon the Booke, was a very compleat Letter, and Å¿o Artificially cut, as that to looke on it the uÅ¿uall way, it Å¿eemed a compleat and perfect C, but
turned one Å¿ide of it, and it appeared a Popes head, and then turned another way, and there appeared an Armie of men or Souldiers. And we require you to declare by vertue of your Oath to your beÅ¿t knowledge and beliefe, who or what was meant by the Popes head in the Å¿aid Letter or Å¿eale; and who or what by the Army of men or Souldiers? And who by the C? And whether by the C was ment the Lords Grace of Canterbury? and by the Popes head that his Grace was meant? And that by the Army of men or Souldiers was meant, that his Grace would be the cauÅ¿e of Wars in this Kingdome about Religion, or Å¿ome other like meaning or device,) which is likewiÅ¿e recited in his CenÅ¿ure in like terms.

That your Petitioners Father was ordered to Å¿atisfie 22 pound 13 Å¿hillings 4 pence, for Fees due to the MeÅ¿Å¿enger, who firÅ¿t Å¿eiÅ¿ed him at 6 Å¿h. 8 d. the day, for the 10. weeks he detained him CloÅ¿e PriÅ¿oner, when his Father had nothing to doe with him, he being another mans Servant.

That after your Petitioner had lyen almoÅ¿t two yeares in the Counter, he was by the High CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners ordered to be Å¿ent to Wisbich CaÅ¿tie in the Ile of Elie there to remain a cloÅ¿e PriÅ¿oner. But by a Generall Warrant from the ArchbiÅ¿hop and Å¿ome other Lords he was removed to the Gate-houÅ¿e, and thence after a Å¿hort abode there, removed to the White Lion in Southwarke, where he lay almoÅ¿t a yeare,

That your Petitioner during his Å¿aid ImpriÅ¿onments hath had his Chambers divers times Å¿earched, his Trunks and Boxes broken open; his licenced Books and lawfull papers taken away, and never yet could have them returned.

That your Petitioner hath made Å¿everall humble addreÅ¿Å¿es by petition to the CounÅ¿ell Table, the High CommiÅ¿Å¿ion Court, and Arch-BiÅ¿hop for Reliefe in his inlargement, or Å¿upport, with maintenance, but could not obtaine their Gracious AnÅ¿wers, eÅ¿pecially the Arch-BiÅ¿hop, in regard he had vowed (as his owne HouÅ¿hold Servants reported) that your Petitioner Å¿hould never be releaÅ¿ed as long as he breathed, without he would either Å¿ubmit to
confeÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uch things as Å¿hould be required of him; as, what his Mr. did, and what he bade him to doe; or to take the Oath Ex Officio.

Alwhich Illegall ImpriÅ¿onments of purpoÅ¿e to inforce him to betray and accuÅ¿e his Innocent Mr. againÅ¿t the Laws of God, and the Realme, he humbly Å¿ubmits to the grave ConÅ¿ideration of this Honourable HouÅ¿e, deÅ¿iring Å¿uch Recompence for his Å¿aid falÅ¿e ImpriÅ¿onments and Injuries as to your wiÅ¿domes Å¿hall Å¿eem moÅ¿t meet.

div.p:
THAt your Petitioner (though every way conformable to the Laws of this Realm, and Doctrine and DiÅ¿cipline of the Church of England, and of a peaceable diÅ¿poÅ¿ition) about 3 yeares Å¿ince, for viÅ¿iting Mr. Prynne in his paÅ¿Å¿age through CheÅ¿ter to the CaÅ¿tle of Carnarvan, by the conÅ¿ent of his Keeper, was by the meanes and direction of the BiÅ¿hop of CheÅ¿ter AreÅ¿ted by the Servant of Roger Blanchard PurÅ¿uivant for the High-CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners at Yorke, to appeare before them upon CheÅ¿ter Chaire Evening, who forced him to enter into Bond, with Sureties to appeare at the Court at BiÅ¿hops-Thorpe on that day, which he did accordingly: And on the Å¿ame day your Petitioners Wife was ArreÅ¿ted, and carryed out

That your Petitioner upon his Appearance was enforced to take an Oath to AnÅ¿were Å¿undry originals, and three papers of Additionall Articles, to his great vexation and expence, being kept at Yorke in the Å¿aid PurÅ¿ulvants houÅ¿e, for the Å¿pace of eight weeks, during which time, he was conÅ¿trained to Å¿end down Å¿everall CommiÅ¿Å¿ions for the Examination of his Wife, being unable to Travell, and dangerouÅ¿ly Å¿ick, by meanes of the fright Å¿he took by the PurÅ¿uivants ArreÅ¿ting her, and carrying her away in the night, Your Petitioners HouÅ¿e, Shoppe, and Study being three times Å¿earched in the meane time, by a Warrant from the Lords. And though nothing offenÅ¿ive was then found, or proved againÅ¿t him, but only his viÅ¿iting Mr. Prynne in his paÅ¿Å¿age through CheÅ¿ter, and that with the leave of his Conductours, Yet your Petitioner was by the Å¿aid CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners fined 300. pound to his MajeÅ¿ty, ImpriÅ¿oned in the PurÅ¿uivants HouÅ¿e, to whom he payed 6. Å¿h. 8. d. a day, beÅ¿ides his diet, untill Å¿uch time as he Å¿hould enter into Bond, with Sureties, to make Å¿uch a publique acknowledgement of his pretended offence, in viÅ¿iting Mr. Prynne, both in the Cathedrall, and Common Hall of CheÅ¿ter, as the Å¿aid
CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners Å¿hould preÅ¿cribe; your Petitioner being enforced to pay divers great and unwarrantable Fees, both to the PurÅ¿uivants, RegiÅ¿ters, Proctors, and other Officers of the Å¿aid Court, to the value of 50. pound at the leaÅ¿t; And though nothing was proved againÅ¿t his Wife, yet they forced him to pay the Charges of the Court, and CoÅ¿ts of Suit for her.

That your Petitioner by reaÅ¿on of his Å¿aid great OppreÅ¿Å¿ions and Expences, and through the perÅ¿waÅ¿ion of the Å¿aid BiÅ¿hop of CheÅ¿ter, and his Chancellour, was moÅ¿t againÅ¿t his Judgement and ConÅ¿cience induced to make an unjuÅ¿t Acknowledgement in the Å¿aid Cathedrall before a great AÅ¿Å¿embly, where the Å¿aid BiÅ¿hop being then preÅ¿ent, and his Chapleyn Mr. Thomas Cordell preaching a Sermon for that purpoÅ¿e, wherein he bitterly inveighed againÅ¿t Mr. Prynne and his Fellow-Å¿ufferers, comparing them to Corah, Dathan and Abiram. And becauÅ¿e your Petitioner changed one word of the Acknowledgement, Å¿aying ignorantly for wickedly, hee was injoyned by the BiÅ¿hop the Å¿ame day at Evening to make a new Acknowledgement in the Å¿aid Church before another Great AÅ¿Å¿embly; and after that, to make the firÅ¿t Acknowledgement in the Common Hall of CheÅ¿ter, before the Maior and Aldermen, and all comers in; And enforced him to pay 4 pound to Blanchard for being preÅ¿ent to Å¿ee his Acknowledgement made.

After which your Petitioner was conÅ¿trained to pay 30. pound to the Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Canterbury, and Sugar-loaves to his Servant Mr. Holford, for CompoÅ¿ition of his Å¿aid Fine of 30. pound; Å¿o that by reaÅ¿on of all the premiÅ¿Å¿es, your Petitioner hath expended at leaÅ¿t the Å¿umme of 100. pound, and Å¿uffered damages to the value of 200. pound in his Trade and Reputation.

div.p:
THAT your Petitioners (though peaceable, and conformable to the Lawes of the Realme, and Doctrine, and DiÅ¿cipline, by Law eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in the Church of England) were about three yeares Å¿ince (with William Trafford DeceaÅ¿ed) ArreÅ¿ted by Roger Blanckhard, chiefe PurÅ¿uivant for the High CommiÅ¿Å¿ion at Yorke, (for ViÅ¿iting Mr. William Prynne in his Journy to Carnarvan CaÅ¿tle, which they conceived they might Lawfully doe, being his friends, and there being no order to the contrary) who upon their Å¿aid ArreÅ¿t, tooke of each of your Petitioners, 3 pound a peece, for his Å¿ees, and Å¿everall
Bonds of your Petitioners, for the appearance at the Å¿aid High-CommiÅ¿Å¿ion at Yorke, within a Å¿hort time after; which they did accordingly, and were committed to the Å¿aid Blanchards cuÅ¿tody, until Å¿uch time as they entred into Bonds, to Å¿tand to the Order of the Å¿ame Court: And upon your Petitioners appearance, divers Articles were exhibited againÅ¿t them, in the Å¿aid Court; and the viÅ¿iting of the Å¿aid William Prynne, they confeÅ¿Å¿ed, but denyed all miÅ¿cariages, or miÅ¿demeanors, charged againÅ¿t them, and averred that they accompanied him onely in the preÅ¿ence of his Keepers. And your Petitioner, Peter Leigh, was fined 200 li. to the Kings MajeÅ¿ty: and your other Petitioner 300 li. and the Å¿aid William Trafford, 150 li. and for the Å¿ame cauÅ¿e, and not any witneÅ¿Å¿e examined againÅ¿t any of them, were enjoyned to make an acknowledgement, which before they would not do, in regard the Å¿ame was againÅ¿t
their conÅ¿ciences, and the Lawes of this Realme as they beleeved; They were forced to flee into other Countries, and leave their Wives, and Children, Trades, and ProfeÅ¿Å¿ions; And in their abÅ¿ence the PurÅ¿uivants of the Å¿aid Court came to their HouÅ¿es, with Warrants, or intimations, which they cauÅ¿ed to be publiÅ¿hed in your Petitioners PariÅ¿h Churches in CheÅ¿ter aforeÅ¿aid, and did Å¿o affright their Wives, that they being with Child, did Å¿oone after miÅ¿carry.

And your Petitioners, and William Trafford, uÅ¿ing all meanes for their freedome, could not prevaile, but their fines were EÅ¿treated, and their Bonds returned into the Exchequer as forfeited; whereupon at laÅ¿t, that they might have Å¿ome acceÅ¿Å¿e, and favour, to and with the Arch-BiÅ¿hop of Canturbury, who, as they were informed, had onely power to relieve them; They payd Doctor Merricke, one of the Advocates of the High-CommiÅ¿Å¿ion Court at Canterbury, that they might have acceÅ¿Å¿e to his LordÅ¿hip, 35 li. at Å¿everall times: They preÅ¿ented his LordÅ¿hip alÅ¿o with two Butts of the beÅ¿t Sacke, and gave one Mr. Holford, one of his Attendants 12 li. and other Gratuities, to other of his Servants, to the value of 20 li. more. was content to take, and did take for your Petitioners and the Å¿aid Traffords fines 240 li. more which they payd accordingly, and were forced to pay 40 li. more for fees in London, and at Yorke concerning the Å¿aid buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e; by which Å¿aid expence, troubles, and neglect of their owne OccaÅ¿ions, your Petitioners for their parts, have beene damnified above 1000 li. and their eÅ¿tates almoÅ¿t thereby wholly mined: They being enforced to flee and wander into Å¿trange Countries for about foure moneths together: your Petitioner Peter Leigh, then being a TradeÅ¿man, who dealt for above 4000 li. per annum, and then much indebted, had his Shop Å¿hut up, for above 3 moneths together, for feare of having his goods Å¿eized, for his forfited Bond, and fine aforeÅ¿aid. And your Petitioner Golborne thereby was Å¿o ruined in his EÅ¿tate, that he for a long time after, with his Wife, and Children, lived upon the Benevolence of his Friends, and now is conÅ¿trained to live in Service, being diÅ¿abled for want of moneyes to goe on in that courÅ¿e wherein formerly he was imployed.

May it therfore pleaÅ¿e this Honourable AÅ¿Å¿emblie to take your Petitioners diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed eÅ¿tate into your grave ConÅ¿iderations, and to weigh their pretended Offences, and their Å¿evere and heavie puniÅ¿hments together, and to afford them Å¿uch Reliefe for the great wrongs done unto them, and their
EÅ¿tates and Families by the CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners and Officers of the Å¿aid High CommiÅ¿Å¿ion, who have Å¿o rent and torne them in their EÅ¿tates, as aforeÅ¿aid; and by thoÅ¿e who are the Authours of their Grievances and OppreÅ¿Å¿ions, who have made a prey of them, by taking Å¿uch Gratuities and Å¿ummes of money of them, as aforeÅ¿aid; when they or Å¿ome of them were the Incendiaries of their Troubles and Vexations, and the Authors and procurers of their Å¿o heavie puniÅ¿hments, as in your grave WiÅ¿domes Å¿hall Å¿eem convenient; That Å¿o other his MajeÅ¿ties Subjects for the time future, may not be Å¿o grievouÅ¿ly oppreÅ¿Å¿ed at mans pleaÅ¿ure.
